question: What is a premium?
options: The amount you pay for your insurance policy
The amount you pay when visiting a doctor
The maximum your insurance covers annually
A bonus payment when you don't use your insurance
correctAnswer: The amount you pay for your insurance policy

question: What does the term 'deductible' mean in health insurance?
options: The amount deducted from your paycheck for insurance
The amount you must pay before your insurance begins to pay
The discount you receive for being healthy
The maximum amount your plan will cover
correctAnswer: The amount you must pay before your insurance begins to pay

question: What is coinsurance?
options: Having multiple insurance policies
The percentage of costs you pay after meeting your deductible
Insurance you share with your spouse
The insurance company's portion of the bill
correctAnswer: The percentage of costs you pay after meeting your deductible

question: What is a copayment or "copay"?
options: A fixed amount you pay for a covered service
The cost of adding someone to your policy
A payment arrangement plan
The fee for changing insurance providers
correctAnswer: A fixed amount you pay for a covered service

question: What does "out-of-pocket maximum" refer to?
options: Cash you keep in your wallet for medical emergencies
The most you will pay during a policy period before insurance covers 100%
Money you save in a health savings account
The maximum amount your insurance will pay annually
correctAnswer: The most you will pay during a policy period before insurance covers 100%

question: What is the difference between an HMO and PPO plan?
options: HMOs require referrals for specialists and limit network coverage; PPOs offer more flexibility but typically cost more
HMOs cost more but provide better coverage; PPOs are cheaper with limited coverage
HMOs cover dental and vision; PPOs only cover medical
There is no difference; they are alternative names for the same type of plan
correctAnswer: HMOs require referrals for specialists and limit network coverage; PPOs offer more flexibility but typically cost more

question: What is a Health Savings Account (HSA)?
options: An emergency fund managed by your employer
A tax-advantaged savings account for medical expenses, only available with high-deductible health plans
A payment plan for medical bills
A government subsidy for low-income individuals
correctAnswer: A tax-advantaged savings account for medical expenses, only available with high-deductible health plans

question: What is an explanation of benefits (EOB)?
options: A marketing brochure explaining insurance benefits
A statement from your insurance company showing what was paid on your claim
A doctor's note explaining your medical condition
The fine print section of your insurance policy
correctAnswer: A statement from your insurance company showing what was paid on your claim

question: What does "in-network" mean?
options: Providers who have contracted with your insurance company to provide services
Doctors who work at the same hospital
Healthcare professionals who are connected online
A group of specialists who work together
correctAnswer: Providers who have contracted with your insurance company to provide services

question: What is a formulary?
options: A mathematical equation used to calculate premiums
A list of prescription drugs covered by your insurance plan
A form you submit for reimbursement
The formula used to determine your deductible
correctAnswer: A list of prescription drugs covered by your insurance plan

question: What is "balance billing"?
options: When you can spread your premium payments over time
When a provider bills you for the difference between their charge and what insurance paid
When your account is settled to zero
A method of tracking medical expenses
correctAnswer: When a provider bills you for the difference between their charge and what insurance paid

question: What is a prior authorization?
options: Permission given by your primary care doctor to see a specialist
Approval from your insurance company required before certain services are covered
Permission to access your medical records
An agreement to pay medical expenses upfront
correctAnswer: Approval from your insurance company required before certain services are covered

question: What is the difference between an embedded and non-embedded deductible?
options: Embedded: each family member has own deductible. Non-Embedded: family must meet one large deductible
Embedded: apply to hospital stays. Non-Embedded apply to outpatient care
Embedded: reset annually. Non-Embedded roll over
There is no difference; these are marketing terms
correctAnswer: Embedded: each family member has own deductible. Non-Embedded: family must meet one large deductible

question: What is a high-deductible health plan (HDHP)?
options: Any plan with an expensive monthly premium
A plan that requires you to pay most costs out-of-pocket
A health plan with lower premiums but higher deductibles that meets IRS criteria for HSA eligibility
A plan specifically for catastrophic illnesses
correctAnswer: A health plan with lower premiums but higher deductibles that meets IRS criteria for HSA eligibility

question: What is an exclusive provider organization (EPO)?
options: A plan that only covers emergency services
A hybrid plan offering HMO pricing with PPO flexibility, but no out-of-network coverage except emergencies
A luxury insurance option for executives
A plan exclusively for preventive care
correctAnswer: A hybrid plan offering HMO pricing with PPO flexibility, but no out-of-network coverage except emergencies

question: Sarah just started a new job and must choose between two health plans. Plan A has a monthly premium of $200 with a $2,000 deductible. Plan B has a monthly premium of $300 with a $1,000 deductible. If Sarah rarely needs medical care, which plan might be more economical for her?
options: Plan A
Plan B
Both would cost the same
Not enough information to decide
correctAnswer: Plan A

question: John has met his $1,500 deductible for the year. His plan has 20% coinsurance for specialist visits. If he sees a specialist who charges $200, how much will John pay?

Maria's insurance plan has a $30 copay for primary care visits and a $50 copay for specialist visits. She has not met her deductible yet. How much will she pay for a visit to her primary care physician?
options: The full cost of the visit
The full cost minus $30
correctAnswer: The full cost of the visit

question: Tom has a plan with a $5,000 out-of-pocket maximum. He has already paid $4,800 in deductibles and coinsurance this year. He now needs a procedure that costs $1,000, with 20% coinsurance. How much will Tom pay for this procedure?
options: $200, but he'll only pay $200 of that because of his out-of-pocket maximum

question: Lisa has a PPO plan and wants to see a dermatologist. What is typically true about her situation?
options: She must get a referral from her primary care physician
She can make an appointment directly with any dermatologist
She must choose from a specific list of dermatologists
She must pay the full cost regardless of network status
correctAnswer: She can make an appointment directly with any dermatologist

question: David has a family of four on his health insurance plan with an embedded deductible of $1,000 per person and $3,000 for the family. His son has met his individual $1,000 deductible, but no one else has had medical expenses. If David now has a $1,500 medical bill, how much of that will apply toward his deductible?
options: $0, because the family deductible is already met

question: Emma is comparing two insurance plans. Plan X has a premium of $250/month with a $40 copay for specialist visits. Plan Y has a premium of $200/month but uses 20% coinsurance for specialist visits after the deductible is met. Emma expects to see specialists frequently for a chronic condition. Which factor should she consider most important?
options: The total annual premium difference
The typical cost of her specialist visits
Whether she's likely to meet her deductible early in the year
All of the above
correctAnswer: All of the above

question: Carlos takes a specific medication monthly that costs $500. His insurance has a three-tier prescription formulary with $10/$35/$60 copays. What should Carlos do to determine his out-of-pocket cost?
options: Pay $500 each month since prescription drugs aren't covered
Check which tier his medication falls under in the formulary
Calculate 20% of the medication cost
Ask his doctor to provide free samples
correctAnswer: Check which tier his medication falls under in the formulary

question: Jennifer has an HMO plan and needs to see a dermatologist. What is the correct process she should follow?
options: Call her insurance company for approval
Visit any dermatologist and submit the bill to insurance
Get a referral from her primary care physician
Pay out-of-pocket since specialists aren't covered
correctAnswer: Get a referral from her primary care physician

question: Mark has a plan with a $2,500 deductible and 30% coinsurance with an out-of-pocket maximum of $6,000. He has a hospital stay costing $10,000. If he has not paid any medical expenses yet this year, how much will he pay for this hospital stay?
options: $4,750 ($2,500 deductible + 30% of remaining $7,500)
correctAnswer: $4,750 ($2,500 deductible + 30% of remaining $7,500)

question: Sophia has an EPO plan and experiences a medical emergency while traveling out-of-state. What is typically true about her coverage?
options: She has no coverage since she's outside her network area
She's covered the same as in-network for emergency services
She must pay upfront and request reimbursement
She must return to her home state for treatment
correctAnswer: She's covered the same as in-network for emergency services

question: Jason's employer offers an HDHP with an HSA. His health expenses are usually minimal, but he wants to save for future medical needs. If his plan has a $3,000 deductible and he contributes $2,000 to his HSA this year, which statement is correct?
options: His effective deductible is reduced to $1,000
His HSA contributions can be used tax-free for qualified medical expenses and unspent funds roll over year to year
He must spend all HSA funds by the end of the year
HSA funds can only be used after meeting the deductible
correctAnswer: His HSA contributions can be used tax-free for qualified medical expenses and unspent funds roll over year to year

question: Rebecca receives a bill for $500 from an anesthesiologist after surgery, even though her hospital was in-network. Her insurance paid the surgeon and hospital but denied the anesthesiologist claim. What is this situation called and what should Rebecca do?
options: Coordination of benefits issue; call her secondary insurance
Surprise billing/balance billing; contact her insurance to dispute the bill
Usual and customary limit; pay the difference
Premium deficiency; increase her coverage level
correctAnswer: Surprise billing/balance billing; contact her insurance to dispute the bill

question: Miguel's insurance has a $3,000 deductible, 20% coinsurance, and $7,000 out-of-pocket maximum. He's already paid $2,500 toward his deductible and $3,500 total out-of-pocket this year. He now needs a procedure costing $20,000. Calculate his financial responsibility.
options: $500 deductible + $3,900 coinsurance (20% of $19,500) = $4,400
$3,500, since he's already paid that amount
$3,500 remaining to reach his out-of-pocket maximum
$500 deductible + coinsurance until reaching the out-of-pocket maximum = $3,500
correctAnswer: $500 deductible + coinsurance until reaching the out-of-pocket maximum = $3,500

question: Alejandra's insurance plan states it covers preventive care at 100% but diagnostic care subject to deductible and coinsurance. She goes for a screening colonoscopy (preventive), but the doctor removes a polyp during the procedure. How might this affect her bill?
options: The entire procedure remains preventive and is covered 100%
The procedure may be reclassified as diagnostic, subject to cost-sharing
Only the polyp removal portion will be billed separately
Her preventive care benefit is forfeited for the year
correctAnswer: The procedure may be reclassified as diagnostic, subject to cost-sharing

question:
The Jackson family has a choice between three plans:
Plan A: $400/month premium, $1,000 deductible, 20% coinsurance, $4,000 out-of-pocket max
Plan B: $300/month premium, $2,500 deductible, 20% coinsurance, $6,000 out-of-pocket max
Plan C: $200/month premium, $5,000 deductible, 30% coinsurance, $8,000 out-of-pocket max
If they expect approximately $5,000 in medical expenses this year, which plan would likely be most economical?
options: Plan A
Plan B
Plan C
All would cost roughly the same
correctAnswer: All would cost roughly the same

question: Kyle has a chronic condition requiring frequent specialist visits and expensive medications. Which plan features should be his highest priority when selecting insurance?
options: Low premium and high deductible
Low specialist copays and favorable prescription coverage
Low out-of-pocket maximum and good coverage for his specific medications
Coverage for alternative treatments
correctAnswer: Low out-of-pocket maximum and good coverage for his specific medications

question: Emily is 28, healthy, and has savings. She rarely sees doctors but wants protection against unexpected major expenses. Her employer offers: Standard PPO: $350/month, $1,000 deductible, $4,000 out-of-pocket max; HDHP with HSA: $200/month, $3,000 deductible, $6,000 out-of-pocket max with $50/month employer HSA contribution. Which makes more financial sense for her situation?
options: Standard PPO for better coverage
HDHP with HSA for lower premiums and tax advantages
Decline insurance and pay out-of-pocket
Purchase insurance directly from marketplace instead
correctAnswer: HDHP with HSA for lower premiums and tax advantages

question: Daniel's child needs speech therapy. Plan A covers 24 sessions per year with a $30 copay. Plan B covers medically necessary sessions at 80% after deductible. Which key questions should Daniel ask before deciding?
options: What therapists are in-network for each plan?
How does each plan determine medical necessity for therapy?
What is the typical cost per session if paying coinsurance?
All of the above
correctAnswer: All of the above

question: The Rodriguez family includes parents and three children. One child has asthma requiring regular medications and occasional urgent care visits. Which type of plan structure might be most beneficial?
options: An HDHP with family deductible to maximize HSA contributions
A plan with an embedded deductible structure
A plan with the lowest possible deductible regardless of premium
A plan with specialized asthma coverage
correctAnswer: A plan with an embedded deductible structure

question:
Jamie receives an explanation of benefits showing:

Provider charge: $1,200
Plan discount: $500
Plan paid: $560
Patient responsibility: $140

Which statement explains this breakdown?
options: Jamie has a 50% coinsurance rate
Jamie received a 50% discount for using an in-network provider
The insurance negotiated a discount and paid 80% of the allowed amount
Jamie has already met her deductible
correctAnswer: The insurance negotiated a discount and paid 80% of the allowed amount

question: Ryan's doctor recommends an MRI that costs $1,500. His insurance requires prior authorization. What happens if Ryan proceeds without getting authorization?
options: The insurance will still cover it if medically necessary
Ryan will pay a penalty but still receive coverage
The insurance may deny coverage completely
The MRI facility won't perform the procedure
correctAnswer: The insurance may deny coverage completely

question:
Zoe's insurance card shows:

PCP copay: $25
Specialist copay: $45
ER copay: $250 (waived if admitted)
Rx: $15/$30/$50

What does the last line indicate?
options: The cost for different quantities of medication (15/30/50 pills)
The copay for prescriptions at different pharmacy tiers
The copay for generic/preferred brand/non-preferred medications
The copay for prescriptions based on days' supply
correctAnswer: The copay for generic/preferred brand/non-preferred medications

question: Marcus has a family HDHP with a $6,000 deductible. His wife is pregnant. What financial planning should they consider?
options: Expect to pay up to $6,000 out-of-pocket for all prenatal and delivery care
Budget for copays only since maternity care is preventive
Verify which prenatal services are preventive (covered 100%) vs. subject to deductible
Switch plans mid-year to get better maternity coverage
correctAnswer: Verify which prenatal services are preventive (covered 100%) vs. subject to deductible

question: Priya sees that her insurance offers telemedicine visits for $10 vs. $30 for in-office visits. What considerations should factor into her decision about using this service?
options: Telemedicine is always preferable since it costs less
The appropriateness of her medical condition for virtual care
In-office visits are always more thorough
Telemedicine isn't real healthcare
correctAnswer: The appropriateness of her medical condition for virtual care

question:
Lucas is choosing between two jobs with different benefits:

Job A: $60,000 salary with premium-free health insurance, $2,000 deductible
Job B: $65,000 salary with $300/month premium, $1,000 deductible

How should he evaluate the true compensation difference?
options: Job B pays $5,000 more, making it the better choice
Calculate annual health insurance costs and expected medical expenses for both scenarios
Job A is better because free insurance is worth more than $5,000
The deductible difference is most important regardless of premium
correctAnswer: Calculate annual health insurance costs and expected medical expenses for both scenarios

question: Nadia is enrolled in her employer's plan but her spouse has access to insurance through his own employer. What factors should they consider when deciding whether to enroll separately or together on one plan?
options: Only the premium differences
Compare networks, total costs, and whether their employer charges a surcharge for spouse coverage
Always choose the husband's plan
Always choose separate plans for maximum coverage
correctAnswer: Compare networks, total costs, and whether their employer charges a surcharge for spouse coverage

question: Wei is considering a plan with a $3,000 deductible and eligibility for an HSA. His employer contributes $500 annually to the HSA. What's the maximum amount Wei can personally contribute to his HSA this year (2025) if he's single?
options: $4,150 (the 2025 IRS limit of $4,650 minus the $500 employer contribution)
Unlimited contributions
$500 to match the employer
correctAnswer: $4,150 (the 2025 IRS limit of $4,650 minus the $500 employer contribution)

question: Which of these preventive services is generally covered at 100% with no cost-sharing under most insurance plans?
options: Annual physical exam
Treatment for an identified condition
Diagnostic testing for symptoms
Cosmetic procedures
correctAnswer: Annual physical exam

question: Gabriela is reviewing health plans during open enrollment. Her current medications cost $300/month without insurance. What steps should she take to evaluate prescription coverage?
options: Choose the plan with the lowest premium
Check each plan's formulary to see which tier her medications fall under
Ask her doctor to switch all medications to generics
Assume all plans cover prescriptions the same way
correctAnswer: Check each plan's formulary to see which tier her medications fall under

question: Diego received a medical bill he believes insurance should have covered. What should be his first step?
options: Pay the bill to avoid collection notices
Call the provider's billing office
Compare the bill with his explanation of benefits
File a complaint with the state insurance commissioner
correctAnswer: Compare the bill with his explanation of benefits

question: Leila's claim was denied because the service was deemed not medically necessary. What options does she have?
options: Pay the bill since insurance has made its decision
File an appeal with supporting documentation from her doctor
Switch insurance companies immediately
Report her doctor for recommending unnecessary treatment
correctAnswer: File an appeal with supporting documentation from her doctor

question: Omar is starting a new medication that's not covered by his formulary. What potential solution could his doctor help with?
options: Submit a formulary exception request
Bill the medication as a different drug
Advise Omar to change insurance plans
Suggest paying cash without using insurance
correctAnswer: Submit a formulary exception request

question: Keisha's son needs urgent care for an injury while they're on vacation in another state. Her plan is a nationally-recognized PPO. What should she do?
options: Return to their home state for treatment
Seek care and expect coverage at out-of-network rates
Call her insurance's nurse line before seeking care
Check her insurer's website/app for nearby in-network urgent care facilities
correctAnswer: Check her insurer's website/app for nearby in-network urgent care facilities

question: Brandon notices that his employer offers a flexible spending account (FSA) for healthcare expenses. How does this differ from an HSA?
options: FSA funds can be used for more types of expenses
FSA funds typically expire at year-end unlike HSA funds that roll over
FSA contributions are not tax-advantaged
FSAs are only for dental and vision expenses
correctAnswer: FSA funds typically expire at year-end unlike HSA funds that roll over
